CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, National Edition, October 31, 1942, pg. 15, reads: "The oldest registered druggist in Pittsburgh, and probably Western Pennsylvania, is John D. Crampton. Nicknamed "Grampy" by his friends, he has been dispensing drugs at 1403 Wylie avenue for the past 36 years. Mr. Crampton states, "years of experience have taught me the value of capitalizing on the advertising campaigns that are run in papers which are read by my customers." The picture above showing the attractive Phillip Morris window display which Crampton had placed in his store, certainly confirms his statement. Standing beside Crampton is one of his clerks Samuel Golden, a second year student in the Duquesne school of pharmacy. - Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: John "Grampy" Crampton on left, next to Pharmacy clerk Samuel Golden, standing in front of Crampton's Pharmacy, with Philip Morris display in window, 1403 Wylie Avenue, Hill District
